title: Compact extruder for Prusa i3 and 42YF22GN050R (2engineers) geared motor with shaft support

description.text:
This thing is a modified version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:69342
More parametrised.
This is a drop in replacement for Greg's Wade geared extruder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18379 on my Prusa i3.
Filament - 1.75 mm.
BOM

• 42YF22GN050R - geared motor
  • MK7 drive gear
  • 3 x 624zz bearings (2 for support, 1 as idler)
  • 6 x M4 washers (around each bearing)
  • 5 x M4x20 socket head screws
  • 5 x M4 nuts (I use 3 x M4x16 without nuts for bearing mounts)
  • 2 x M3x16 socket head screws (for motor mount)
  • 4 x M3 nuts (2 - motor mount, 2 - for idler fasteners)
  • 2 x M3 washers (idler fasteners)
  • 2 x M3x35 socket head screws (idler fasteners)
  • 2 x springs (I bought them in weapon shop as parts from pistol)
  • I'm use short PTFE tube from E3D hotend to drive gear.
    • Settings

8 microsteps.
Retraction length: 0.5 mm
Retraction speed: 30 mm/s. Motor (42YF22GN050R) parameters for Marlin firmware: #define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT ...567 #define DEFAULT_MAX_FEEDRATE ...35 #define DEFAULT_MAX_ACCELERATION ...300 #define DEFAULT_RETRACT_ACCELERATION 300 UPDATE 13-SEP-2014
Added long screws, springs, washers, nuts for idler.

comments.text: How it is going? I have mine working great with 3mm and was wondering  how fast it could be with 1,75 filament

comments.text:
I don't like it. Slow retraction speed/acceleration.
I have developed a geared extruder with light stepper motor (http://goo.gl/RQB5dM) and now I'm happy.

title: Blower duct for MakerFarm i3v print cooler

description.text: Variation of darco's 50mm blower duct optimized to be used with a Delta BVB0512VHD-SP01 radial blower mounted to the left side of the X-carriage on MakerFarm i3v series printers. Makes a great print cooling system for the i3v. More information on the i3v print cooler approach can be found at http://3dprintboard.com/showthread.php?3461-MakerFarm-8-quot-i3v-Prusa-build-by-Printbus&p=26657&viewfull=1#post26657

This duct is intended to slip inside the blower outlet. The STL file provided should work fine for MakerFarm i3v printers and the Delta BFB0512VHD-SP01 blower.   Tailor the parameters in the openSCAD file for other applications or other blowers.  No support should be required as long as the duct is printed in the upright orientation.

comments.text: Note that Delta has transitioned the BFB0512VHD-SP01 blower to obsolete part status. Those with the design in a collection for future build may want to obtain the blower while stock is still available from DigiKey - http://www.digikey.com/product-search/en?x=0&y=0&lang=en&site=us&keywords=bfb0512vhd-sp01.
comments.author: Printbus

To secure the camera you also need 2 srews M2 x 12 mm.
The small camera took a surprisingly good video: http://youtu.be/FHDhLBsC3_M

author: wersy

title: The PushSter : The Ultimate Tablesaw Pusher
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I bring you a 3D Printable remake of a very popular all-plastic product from the world of WoodWorking.
This item provides forces in ALL FOUR directions for feeding your work through the table-saw.
This project is a mega-print, and will require a lot of time to produce.
I wouldn't recommend printing the giant flat piece with 2 slots..just make it out of wood or plastic if possible.
UPDATE
9/14/14 Found a blatant issue with hole alignment on the Front Support mating with the Front Grab; fixed.
Added recessed cut-outs for fastening the Front and Rear Grabs to the Heart, so they can mount "flush" without protrusions.
Please download -R2 versions of the pieces if available.

comments.text: Can`t wait to try this... PLA or ABS you think?
comments.author: e3mcreation

comments.text: PLA is a naturally brittle material whereas ABS deforms before it breaks. Due to this and the resonant nature of the tool it accompanies (vibrating saws) I would actually recommend nylon...haha. ABS I believe is a decent choice as well but won't last nearly as long as nylon.
comments.author: e3mcreation

comments.text: It would be nice for novice in woodworking if you make a video showing the use of this tool
comments.author: Tinchus2009

comments.text: Thank you! However I am lower than a novice at both camera operation and narration. Wouldn't be of much help I am afraid. However the commercial tool this is modeled after has a great media team ;) the concepts are identical.
comments.author: Tinchus2009

comments.text: hi, i hope you dont mind the changes i made to it. [i posted a pic] I found the handle too small for my hands (comfort contributes to safety) i was wondering if you minded if i printed a few for the members of my wood working guild?
comments.author: bertorrz

comments.text: Please do! Glad you changed the handle as it was merely arbitrary off of measurements from a few pans and pot handles.
comments.author: bertorrz

comments.text: Outstanding! I was just sitting down to model this.  Printing now in 3D Solutech Carbon Fiber. I think I'll try rubber shelf liner glued on the bottom.
comments.author: thecadman99

comments.text:
Hello,
Thanks for taking the time to note your suggestions! I sure appreciate it.
I work professionally with manufacturing so 4 nicely phrased suggestions doesn't even make me wince! I realize it is not absolutely finished hence the work in progress status :)
Re suggestions.
comments.author: thecadman99

comments.text: Just at a glance, it's looks like it's the same layout as a Gripper.  Ie, are your sidwalls compatible with a commercial Grippper?  I'd like to make some 1/8" (and less) sidewalls, and was planning ot design it myself, but why reinvent the wheel if you did already?
comments.author: marmotjr

comments.text:
What is this gripper you speak of? ;)
I actually designed this based off of an understanding of the workings of the commercial model..ie, no critical dimensions aside those based on my own tablesaw and others become specified based off of standard fastener sizing.
comments.author: marmotjr

comments.text: When I try to print out the nut handles, they are tiny, do I need to do something so that they are printing out at the correct size?
comments.author: mrjohnson1100

comments.text: Hello! Try switching units from inches to mm or vice versa. You may also try scaling up by 25.4 times.
comments.author: mrjohnson1100

comments.text: Okay, so I'm going to take a shot at printing this one.  Printing all the pieces at 100% infill, except for the heart, which I'm going to try at 30%.
comments.author: Launch201

comments.text:
1/4 20 1 inch bolt is fine.
I mean some riving knives, saw guards etc can interfere with clearance as can dado blades etc. Bottom flat piece is made to fit your saw.
You could use a hex nut I suppose but the threads can bite plastic nicely if you insert from the front. Feel free to modify the file just make it to spec if you do and not by measuring a hexnut in front of ya. I am in middle of a big move atm so not much time for drafting
comments.author: Launch201

comments.text: What size screws do you recommend?  I haven't printed them yet, but I think that the knobs would be better if there was a spot to epoxy a hex nut into them.
comments.author: jcollie

comments.text: Also all fasteners are standard 1/4 20
comments.author: jcollie

comments.text: Good call on the hex nut channel. When I get time I'll modify the knob and add the channel.
comments.author: jcollie

comments.text: Let us know when you print it. It looks like quite like my Gripper for my table saw which I love.
comments.author: ldabkey

comments.text: Have you printed this yet or is this still in the total design stage?
comments.author: DasWookie

comments.text:
Hello, thanks for the question.
It has not been printed yet, and is in the design stage, as you say. However, I am a certified mechanical draftsman and have made this to spec for my tablesaw. This has been designed for the standardized u.s tablesaw, which uses 3/4" miter slots with t tracks, which are represented within the heart.stl
comments.author: DasWookie

remixed_from.author: Pointedstick
remixed_from.title: RepRap X-carriage for self-aligning bronze bushings

description.text:
I needed a quick way to mount a 60 mm fan to my x-carriage, to later print a proper fan duct. 
This is what I came up with.
Make sure to use cooling if printing in PLA, the angled tabs need it.

Print, mount to carriage, mount fan on top of the angled tabs (it may hit the surface if mounted to the bottom of the tabs). Mounting hardware needed:
2 x M4 screws + nuts (and washers) Notes:
The carriage end is designed to mount onto the existing screws of the belt clamps. Update: made the default twice as thick and the body smaller to make it sturdier. I put grooves on the carriage tabs since I didn't know exactly what distance from the hot end i wanted the fan. The base is longer than necessary as configured, it sticks out quite far, you may want to adjust before printing. The script is almost fully parametric, but I've only tested it with 60 mm fan, you may need to adapt the script slightly for other sizes/tab spacings. There's a few hard coded numbers that should really be variables, but I'm not sure I'm goin to bother...

A parametric recreation of Jeff Latham's Printrbot Feed Wheel. It's basically a knob that presses onto the tip of a stepper motor's flat shaft. Makes it easier to observe the extruder's motion and gives you the option of manually rotating the shaft if need be.
All the dimensions are adjustable - handle size, shaft length, etc. Depending on the design of your printer, you may need to make changes to avoid mechanical interference. For instance, the version I printed is sized to stick out far enough that the handles won't hit the vertical frame. You may also need to tweak the shaft socket size to ensure an easy fit on your motor.
Exciting action footage: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CKsma1QFEoA
Printed feedwheel42.stl in black PLA at 0.3 mm layer height, 2 walls, 3 top/bottom layers, 0.15 honeycomb infill.

author: BluebirdJonas

title: Xlerator Fanatec CSR Elite pedals power tower

description.text:
A must have for Sim Racing with the Fanatec CSR Elite Pedals!
Use with the models XL20 and XL21 Xlerator Wheel Stand using the Fantec Forza Motorsports CSR Elite wheel and pedal set with Sim Racing game Forza Motorsports 4 and XBox 360.
This is a power tower to attach the power supply to the Fanatec CSR Elite pedals. This is so handy! Makes for easy setup. All you have to do is connect the wire from outlet to power box and race. No dangling power supply moving the stand around. Attaches through bottom of pedals in either side channel with screws. Use 11" wire ties to hold power supply to the power tower.
Power tower is open inside with holes for circulation, to help keep power supply cool.
I do not have the Fanatec CSR regular pedals (the Elites have holes in the pedal pads, regulars do not) but sure this tower will work for those pedals also. Someone let me know if it doesn't.
Enjoy!

Was an interesting build with the angles and circles!
Build time at 10% fill, no support, 2hr 14min.
Print without support. Had the ends bow up a little but it is on the bottom where you can't see.
Drill out holes on bottom of tower to fit your screws. Use 10-12 x 3/4" screws. Mount the power supply up on the tower first. Be sure to tie up the supply wire next to power supply with 11" black wire ties. There are a couple reliefs cut in side of tower for wire ties. Trim wire ties with dikes. Place it in either channel in the pedals and screw through bottom of pedals using the slotted holes. Tape wires up the leg a bit with black electrical tape so they don't get pinched folding the pedal pan up for storage.

This is a 100mm ID Guidescope Ring that will fit to a Celestron Dovetail Rail.

I Printed with these settings;
Layer Height: 0.25mm
Shells: 2
Infill: 100% (could possible reduce this, but my Scope cost a lot and I didn't want to take any chances)
Print each piece (Ring and Ringbase) then use 3mm screws to join them together.
Get thumb screws (5mm) 3x per ring from Lowes to hold you guidescope in the middle of the rings.
Use an additional thumb screw (5mm) per Ringbase to tighten it on the Dovetail mount.

description.text: I lost the rubber feet that came with my 3Up 3D printer, so I designed these to replace them. There is a single hole that you can use to bolt them to the frame to make sure they don't come off, in case you move your printer around a lot. The photo I attached, shows my completed printed foot, but this version did not have the mounting hole in it yet. If you have any comments or suggestions, feel free to contact me!

comments.text: Hi i have a Problem with my 3D printer Can you help me with it, It keeps on messing up when i turn off rafts. Here is the video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nc8LhhH7BAA
comments.author: Spychris101

comments.text: Slow your first layer waaaaay down for starters mate, think its going too fast for the filament to stick to the print surface properly. I usually print the first layer at 20% of the actual print speed for the model. Secondly you can try using a bit of PVA glue or prittstick on the glass bed to help it stick better. And last but not least, make sure your bed is leveled properly. The first line in the video goes down pretty well, then when the nozzle moves to the back of the bed it starts messing up so just make sure the nozzle is the same height from the print bed in all 4 corners of the bed. Id try to level n slow down, then try PVA if it still not sticking. Good luck! :)
comments.author: Spychris101

I was bored, so decided today to start designing an 3d printable R/C boat. At the moment I have pockets for electronics (two servos, receiver, battery, etc), but they are made for my specific electronics. THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS, once I am done I will upload everything including the electronics I used. I don't mind redesigning it a bit to fit someone else's electronics.  
For this boat I'd like to make it power by an engine with an aircraft propeller. I'll update the item as I design how to mount it and stuff. Afterwards I'll work on making it possible to power with a regular screw.  
Not sure I will print it, but that will come later.
This is an incomplete design.

My solder buddy has helpful hands but its feet are too small. I designed this base to give my friend some much needed stability. You can modify the design at:
https://tinkercad.com/things/0m4CUWbw6jF Update
Added material to the solder roll holder
160mm x 120mm

I made using tinkercad because I like simple.
https://tinkercad.com/things/0m4CUWbw6jF
Just print and slide the feet into the grooves, fits like a dovetail joint.

author: UltiArjan

description.text:
Filament guide for the New Robo 3D. All printable, no external parts. See my filament spool rollers for tabletop spool holders. The reason I made this is its generally a bad idea to have your spool on top of the printer cause if you drop a 1kg spool onto your glass bed ... just imagine what happens. This could possibly need some refinement, but i already printed and tested it and it works great, now you can have your spool roll on the table to the left or right of your printer.  
Update: I have printed several bad ass prints using this guide now and still no problems with filament feed:)  
Take a look at my other designs for tabletop spool rollers.  
Please take a picture and share if you make one ;)

Print all parts, the endstops and wheel is two prints each. In the wheel drill out the 2mm holes if needed, the endstops are 5mm, if needed, be careful! Do not drill a hole in your hand! You might need to do some trimming on the mount with a file to get it to fit on the printer.

comments.text: Cool idea! Is there enough room to place a sponge inside to clean/dust the filament as it passes through?
comments.author: droidjsmith

comments.text: I really like this concept and it printed great, I felt like it needed something on the side to help feel the filament more smoothly. I took your design and modified it so it was sideways, then I will put it at the end of the slot with your guide in the middle. I will be happy to share this once I print it and know the rest of your parts fit. I hope you don't mind me fiddling with your original design. I will post pics once I get it all set up.
comments.author: gregor616

comments.text: Similar https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:267039
comments.author: DanielTaughinbaugh

comments.text: Yep, the idea by my filament guides and spool rollers are not to have the 1kg roll of destruction elevated 40 cm above a fragile glass bed.
comments.author: DanielTaughinbaugh

comments.text: Cool, I like it. Fortunately mine has never fallen off. Haha
comments.author: Non-ICE

comments.text: There is a saying that goes something like this: Fail to safe. Hehe ;)
comments.author: DanielTaughinbaugh

comments.text: A neat little design, and rather fun to assemble (like Kinder Surprise for grownups)...  But unfortunately, didn't work very well in practice.  The roller wheel separated shortly after I began printing with it in place, allowing enough of a gap for the filament to get wedged between the two pieces, which resulted in the print head climbing the filament, popping off the rods, and shredding the filament while wedged up at the top of the case.  :(  A one piece wheel for the filament to roll over (perhaps wider, with just a bit of a dip in the middle, so it can be printed flat without support) might work better.
comments.author: AutopsyTurvy

comments.text: Mine printed the wheel to be a tight fit, had to hammer it together, if not, superglue bonds really well with PLA :)
comments.author: AutopsyTurvy

description.text:
Make it easier to braid paracord bracelets with a loom.
I designed mine to fit over the edges of the bag i have the things to make them with. If you want to attach it to something else, just make another pair of attachments.
Depending on the distance of your attachments you might need different amount of sliders, knobs, screws, nuts and washers.
M4 screws and nuts for sliders and attachments, M3 to mount the buckle.
Measurements for my cobra bracelets:
Length = Circumference + 4cm (to get some slack)
Amount of paracord = Length * 13
After the main braiding the left over pieces can be folded down under and hidden inside the paracord braid. That way you can re-braid it if you need to use it as a rope, And it looks nicer without the molten mess at the end of the braid.

title: LEGO FPV camera enclosure and mount

description.text: This is an enclosure for the CMQ1993X color board camera. This enclosure provides an 8mm spaced mount that can be secure to the LEGO Technic beam. This mount kit also provides a LEGO Technic mount for a 3 cells 18650 Lithium battery holder. This is part of a Raspberry Pi remote controlled robot. http://bit.ly/1qQukKr

Camera can be source from Amazon or Ebay under CMQ1993X. The battery holder is a MPD BK-18650-PC6 purchased from Digikey. The transmitter is a Boscam TS351 it was purchased as kit with RC805 from Amazon.
The camera was mounted with the outer bezel removed. Enclosure screws are M3 x 15mm. The pivot screw is M3 x 30mm. The battery holder is riveted to the battery mount. The transmiter board is double sided taped to the back of the camera enclosure.

description.text:
With this simple jig, you will be able to make perfectly square cuts for your PVC projects. It is made for use with a standard hacksaw. When solvent welding PVC pipes, square cuts are the key to creating a strong joint which will hold pressure. This jig was made for cutting schedule 40 2'' diameter PVC (2.375'' outside diameter). I will create jigs for other sizes as I need them, but I'll be happy to add any sizes from requests.  
UPDATE: added jigs for schedule 40 pipes in the sizes 1'' and 4''. The large 4'' jig is designed to just fit the build plate of a replicator 1. I tightened the tolerances a bit, but have not tested the new sizes, please report any issues.

I printed in PLA with 2 layers and 10% infill. Just about any structural configuration should do. Reorient the model so the base is on the bottom (duh) so you don't need support. To use, measure where you want to cut, hold the pipe firmly in the jig, and saw away.
UPDATE: If you are having trouble keeping your pipe in place while cutting, printing a second jig will allow you to keep the pipe level with the jig while you cut.

This is a cable chain system that I designed for the 3uP 3D printer. It utilizes chain that I found on Thingiverse (No sense in reinventing the wheel!), and some custom end plates that I designed. It is designed to mount on the back right side of the printer, and to the X Slider (w/ mounting holes) from the 3uP v1.3.1 and newer.
I tried several different mounting points, but for the chain to work smoothly, and not bind up, I mounted it in the only spot I could find. You will need 38-40 chain links and one of each end plate to get it working. Also, make sure you feed your wires through with the largest connector first. I had to remove the connector from the wires for the hot end, but it is simple enough and the wires will snap right back in. Another tip is to feed the wire in small sections of chain, approx 5-8 links at a time, then snap them together. This is a work in progress, and if you have any comments or suggestions, I am all ears. Enjoy!

The idea of this thing is to allow a PCB to be mounted, offset from a surface, using 4 screws. Often when I have to mount a PCB via its holes, I find that:
  • I never have the screws that fit the PCB
  • The screws will short against a nearby track on the PCB
  • I never have the right 'spacers' needed to stop the PCB tracks from shorting against the metal surface it's to be mounted on.
  • The holes in the PCB are not in a convienient location (often unevenly spaced)
    • This design addresses these:
  • The screw holes can be adjusted in size in the .scad file (within limits)
  • The screws press against the plastic mount, so there is no danger of shorting against PCB tracks.
  • The mount has an inbuilt spacing to raise the PCB from the mounting surface. The height can be adjusted in the .scad file.
    • I made these for a custom PCB I was making, but the length can be adjusted in the .scad file so it should work for most PCBs, including Arduinos and the like.

Note you will need to print two of these for each PCB.   
I printed the example shown in 0.4mm layer PLA on my RepRap Huxley. It came out very clean and didn't need any cleaning.

author: Midncoco

description.text:
There are lots of great panel mounting systems out there to enclose your Replicator, but I wanted something a little different, so I came up with my own design.  I bought a sheet of .093" (2.4mm) Lexan at Lowes to make side and front panels to enclose my Replicator 1.  (I also made a hood from this lexan, which I'll post as a different thing.)  Most of the other options didn't allow for the panels to fit flush in the openings, a feature I wanted in my design.
As I was cutting the Lexan I liked the look of the beveled corners on the Replicator and thought I could accentuate that feature with the brackets. For the top support I thought it would be cool to brand the bot a little bit, and came up with the round M coin to replicate the Makerbot logo.  It's not exact (or official), but looks pretty awesome none the less. It uses the same back support tab as the side mounts to attach to the panel and can be printed single color or two toned with dual extrusion or by pausing and swapping colors.

Print 2 of the triangular mounts and 3 of the back support tabs for each side panel, as well as one of the M coins. (Files to print the M coin as one print and the separated files for dual extrusion are included.) I printed them at .27 layer height, 100% fill. You'll also need #4 (or M3) bolts and nuts to attach the panels. I used 3/4" long bolts with washers on either end, because it's what I had on hand. You should be able to use a 1/2" bolt, especially if you don't use washers. For drilling the Lexan panels, I used the back support tab as a guide. Line the raised circular end in the corner of the Lexan (see picture) and drill an appropriate sized hole. Bolt the brackets to the panel then put into place in the opening. You can then turn the back support tabs outward to lock onto the wooden side walls. Tightened the bolts to secure. The back mount tabs are designed to allow the Lexan panels to lie flush with the outer edge of the printer side walls to make it all flush and neat. Just be sure to accurately measure the lexan before you cut it. Just lay out your measurements, score the cut line with a sharp blade several times, turn it over, score the back side once or twice and snap the lexan apart. You may have to lightly sand the edge, but it comes out pretty clean. Note: I currently have not printed the dual extrusion version of the M coin. The files should be correct, and as soon as I print one, I'll upload a picture. Also, these items were created with Autodesk 123D. I've included the 123d source files. UPDATE The dualstrusion files "RepSideMlogo_M and RepSideMlogo_base" were not printing well for me. I've replaced those files with two versions. One lays the "M" on top of the base layer, while the other is two sided, the "M" flows through the entire print and is visible from both sides. Both versions still have the M and border raised on the front. I will post a flat version if anyone is interested..

comments.text: Updated my bot (and the picts) with the freshly dualstrusion printed M logo coin...  I like it better than the single color.

title: gCreate Rocket Ship Flickering Flame Mod

description.text:
This is a mod of the gCreate rocket ship that adds a flickering LED in the rocket plume.
I added a thin tube so that thin wire could be fed though and a hole in the bottom where I inserted the guts from a 34mm diameter (this was the diameter of the base after the top was removed) flickering LED tea light that I bought from a Dollar Store.
I cut off the LED and re-soldered it at the tip of the smoke, and glued the flame over the top of it.
I also modified the flame so there was space for the LED and made it fit in to the engine nozzle on the rocket better than in the original.
Both parts are scaled to 59% of the original size to fit the bed of my Printrbot Jr.
For more details, please refer to the instructions.
http://youtu.be/Yq1u0m0Ch2I

Print the smoke in a white resin (or not, if that's your thing). Print the flame in a translucent filament of a suitable flame color (I had red available).
If you print these without rescaling, you'll need to rescale the original spaceship and top spike to 59% and print those too. If you change the scale from mine, do bear in mind that the hole for the 34mm tea light base will also be scaled. If your tea light (after the original top is removed) is a different diameter, you'll absolutely need to rescale everything so it will fit.
The hole for the wires can easily get blocked during the printing process. On mine the very top end (the cylindrical bit of the smoke piece) was completely blocked and I had to drill it out with a small drill. I then pushed some thin music wire though the hole multiple times to clear out the arcing channel.
Once the channel is clear, you can feed two thin wires through until they come out the bottom where the big hole for the tea light base is. I used mag wire. Whatever wire you use, do make sure it's properly insulated so that there are no shorts!
Take the top off your tea light and cut the original LED wires. Don't loose track of which terminal is which as you'll need to have it wired up with the same polarity at the end. Some permanent ink on one LED terminal and stub left on the base might be a good idea here.
Solder the LED to the wire you inserted in to the smoke hole at the top where the flame will go. You should make sure you have enough spare wire to prevent your soldering iron from melting your print.
Pull the wires gently down so that the LED lead stubs are as close to the top of the smoke as possible. Then solder the other end of the wires to the cut off leads on the tea light base. Again, you have to make sure you didn't reverse the polarity during this whole splicing process.
Check the LED still works by switching on the tea light.
Insert the tea light base in to the hole in the bottom of the smoke and tack it in place with a few dots of glue.
Slide the flame over the LED and glue it to the smoke. If it doesn't down properly, you may want to shave down the smoke cylinder piece a little, or carefully drill out the bottom end of the flame.
Glue your spaceship on top of the flame.
A note on soldering the LED:
I found it quite hard to solder to the wires on my LED. I was using tin-lead solder. I'm not sure what metal the LED wires were, but tinning the leads proved very difficult. I'm an electronics engineer with a background that includes semiconductor packaging and I have a pretty advanced knowledge of soldering metallurgy and processes, and I can't work out what was going on here. I wonder if the leads were aluminum with a very thin plating. Anyway, eventually I got everything to work and quickly glued it all together before something broke.
Your tea light might be different. Mine was from a Dollar Store, as I said. It was so cheap that the electronics for the flashing are embedded in to the LED, rather than being on a separate PCB.

Makes the proper slit design needed to make flexible wood/acrylic parts on a laser cutter.
I couldn't find anything decent out there that allowed me to export custom sized flexi cuts for projects. Doing this by hand drove me crazy so I made this thing. Hope you enjoy!
With this design, you can adjust:
  • Width and height of the output area
  • The number of rows
  • Number of lines per row
  • Spacing between lines in a row
    The outputted design is exactly proportional and each row is offset by 50% of the row before so you get consistent lines without having to figure it out yourself.
    If you use this, I'd love to see what you've made!

Adjust the output size, number of rows any anything else you want to adjust and then export a DXF that you can import into your laser cutter program of choice.
I take the export and then draw a cutout box around it based on the design I need but you can do whatever you want with it!
Experiment and play around till you find what works :)

title: Key Cover for Honda Key Fob

description.text: My Honda Key fob broke where the screw is so I created a snap on cover to keep everything tight.

My original files have been lost due to a crappy USB key ring but I have attached a SCAD file that can be adjusted to find the perfect radii. The only cut out I put in the file was the top, you can make your own modifications to the cut out. When I get around to this I will use a saw & file till I get the fit right then put the interfering sphere data into a design package so I can make all the corners nicely rounded.
If anyone beats me to finding the perfect sizes post them in the comments for the rest of us.
Good luck

comments.text: I have added a Honda H logo cutout to the SCAD. It was created using the Inkscape to SCAD plugin. I have included all the various files that I needed to make this happen as I went from AutoCAD to jpg to Inkscape to SCAD. But it looks good. Working on rounding the corners.

title: Controller Mount for the MegaController by MakerLab.Me
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The MegaController snaps into this mount. The mount can be attached via screw mounting holes or with zip-ties to almost any printer. The mount is a very exact, tight fit that snaps around the edges of the PCB without interfering with any connectors.
If you are not familiar with the Megacontroller Board, It is an extremely configurable print controller similar to Ramps 1.4 without the need for a seperate arduino microcontroller. (very competitive price!). It's based on the arduino Mega 2560 but with direct support for several extruder heating elements/motors, Min and Max endstops, several thermistor pins, several servos connections and even extra arduino pins you can configure yourself. It's available on Amazon and the manufacturer's website is makerlab.me
Excellent support via web forum. Update 09/13/2014: Updated STL to remove non-watertight error.

A heavy duty (well, robust) articulated joint

This joint is designed to be made from 6mm mdf laminated together with M8 bolts and spacers as the pivots. 
There are only three manufactured parts in the joint (leaf 1, leaf 2 and a spacer). To get the different configurations, just change the order of the lamination. Some of the pieces have a 3mm deep by 6mm wide slot to allow a bolt (M6) to be inserted (so that it could be mounted)
The joint between the two centre sub assemblies isn't very strong- its just a butt joint. Some interim bolted plate is probably required, but hey, its a thing in progress.
I've allowed bolt holes for adding M4 screws to hold the laminated blocks together (just in case you don't want to rely on glue). 
Enjoy

At Mount Pleasant Cemetery, one of the oldest cemeteries in Sioux Falls, South Dakota, stands this poignant grave marker in honor of a young woman who died too soon. There is religious symbolism with the display of a rose, a palm frond and sunflower(?) in a frame near the top of the stone. less wobbly y-idler for the einstein variant (M10 threaded rods) of the Prusa-i3  
so far all y-ilder have the problem that a) they are mounted on only one rod and hence rotate/wobble and b) since they mount on the upper rod, the points at which the timing belt is mounted are not co-liniear = the timing belt is stretched into a triangle, which exacerbates the movement/wobble of the one-point-mount idler  
this variant tries to fix these two issues

print:
1x block
1x flanged_pulley
2x spacer
2x side
other material:
2x M4 nut
2x M4 screw
1x 624zz bearing

comments.text: It really works. I had started to have problems with the y axis when it reached its limits but this helped balance out what was wrong.

author: Bill1961

description.text:
This thing is derived from the oboe stand I posted a few days ago. By refining the design a little, and adding one more component (a joiner), it becomes a stand for two instruments. These will usually be oboe and cor anglais, but they could be almost anything that fits on.
It comes to pieces for travelling, and can be assembled without the joiner to make a smaller single stand, when needed for crowded pit orchestras for example.
By printing extra parts, this stand could be extended to take 3 or more instruments. That might be useful in Bach's Matthew Passion! An oboe d'amoré also fits on.

I printed with a layer height of 0.10mm and fill of 100% in ABS. This seems to be just fine. Using a raft helps to get it unstuck from the bed when it (finally) finishes. I do not recommend less than 100% fill because it needs to be strong. It's possible to get all parts at once onto the bed of a MakerBot. While this approach takes 30 hours or so to finish, it does mean fewer interventions. This version is better in several ways than the one I posted the other day.

3mm to 5mm ID bearing mod

I could not find 3mm ID bearings any where but could find 5mm ID bearings every where!  Very common size for RC cars.  Moded to hold new bearing as well added pin into design. Uses all same hardware and printed same as original.  Bearing size 5mm-10mm-4mm
I should state that I printed the part on its side, just like in the pics shown. I used the same settings as original - in fill- 100% / shell- 1 / temp 230 / speed 80. No raft and no supports. I did drill out the area to fit the M3 bolt but not all the way. I but the bearing in place along with the bearing cover, then slowly ran the brill in. Stopped just as it want to go threw the back.

comments.text: Thanks for the mod - all I could find were 5x10x4 bearings too.  (Bearings at HobbyTownUSA PHU3504.  Screws and spring found at Ace Hardware.)

V5: Bigger holes so screws fit more easily, more holes for mounting, slight changes in hole alignments for easier zip-tying, slightly expanded side supports for the Samantha. Also added version with no side holes to save space for vertically mounted Samanthas. Mounting bracket for a FIRST Tech Challenge (FTC) Samantha module, which can be printed on a bed with a 4.6" square printable surface. Simple modification of the bracket in the link below, with top corners cut off to make it slightly smaller.
http://www.andymark.com/product-p/am-sambracket.htm
Thanks to AndyMark and to FTC4251 for making the original part!

Two  mounts I made up for the Immersion 5.8ghz 600mW VTX.  
One was designed for mounting horizontally on my QAV-250. This one has a support area for the right angle antenna connector.  
The other is designed for mounting vertically on square booms (as in Tri-copters) and can be customized for the boom width.  The cut-outs allow for relatively easy access to change the channel dip switches.
